More Notes: SCC can change by a factor of four if one assumes a quadratic damage function. Year is the publication year, as no specific year for the outcome is given.
Total anthropogenic forcing reaches approximately 8.5W/m2 in the year 2100 under RCP85.
Radiative forcing peaks at approximately 3 W/m2 around 2050 under RCP26.
Radiative forcing declines to approximately 2.6W/m2 at the end of the twenty-ﬁrst century under RCP26.

The page provides comparisons of SCC across different calibrated models and scenarios relative to CDICE-2.6, where CDICE RCP2.6 is normalized to 1, but does not specify exact numerical values for other scenarios at a particular year like 2050. The value 1 here represents the normalization of the CDICE RCP2.6 scenario.
Linear Damage Function; Pessimistic scenarios can lead to three to five times higher SCC compared to optimistic scenarios; minimum effect
Linear Damage Function; Pessimistic scenarios can lead to three to five times higher SCC compared to optimistic scenarios; maximum effect
Linear Damage Function; SCC increases by about 20% relative to the MMM.
Cubic Damage Function; SCC for the most pessimistic climate scenario can be almost eight times the SCC for the most optimistic scenario.
SCC for an ECS of 2.15 using the ECS parameter in CDICE is about 15% too large relative to GISS-E2-R
SCC for an ECS of 4.55 using the ECS parameter in CDICE is about 10% too small relative to CDICE-HadGEM2-ES
DICE-2016 underestimates the SCC substantially by about 20% compared to CDICE for a discount factor of 0.96
DICE-2016 produces much higher values for the SCC, for a value of 0.99, about 30% larger than CDICE

The SCC is highly sensitive to the growth-adjusted interest rate and the intertemporal elasticity of substitution (IES). The SCC increases over time due to output growth. Different values for the IES parameter ψ greatly affect the social cost of carbon across different specifications, causing significant divergence over time. There's an approximately 50% variation for different values of ψ, but no baseline value is provided on this page.
Optimal warming is dramatic assuming high ψ. 200 years from 2015.
High IES case, warming prescribed by DICE-2016 falls significantly out of the CMIP5 range. 200 years from 2015.
